plausible_answers.text: The destruction of the Kaaba and Grand Mosque

qas.question: What became a cause for the celebration of the Umayyads in later histories?
Who dispatched an army to help the opposition movements?

context: Following the death of Husayn, Ibn al-Zubayr, although remaining in Mecca, was associated with <b4_0>two<b4_0/> opposition movements, one centered in Medina and the other around <a0_0>Kharijites<a0_0/> in Basra and Arabia. Because Medina had been home to Muhammad and his family, including Husayn, word of his death and the imprisonment of his family led to a large opposition movement. In 683, <a1_0><b8_0>Yazid<b8_0/><a1_0/> dispatched an army to subdue both movements. The army suppressed the Medinese opposition at the <a2_0>Battle of al-Harrah<a2_0/>. <b5_0>The Grand Mosque<b5_0/> in Medina was severely damaged and widespread pillaging caused deep-seated dissent. <b6_0>Yazid's army<b6_0/> continued on and laid siege to <a3_0>Mecca<a3_0/>. At some point during the siege, the Kaaba was badly damaged in a fire. <b7_0>The destruction of the Kaaba and Grand Mosque<b7_0/> became a major cause for censure of the Umayyads in later histories of the period.
